awd_titl_txt: RUI:  Path Integral Approach to Ion-Impact Collisions
awd_abstract_narration:
The study of atomic collisions provides important information about one of the fundamental forces of nature. The results of atomic collisions research are widely used in fields such as plasma physics, astrophysics, biophysics, and many other areas. In addition to providing a better overall understanding of heavy-ion collisions, which is the principal focus of the effort, this work will bring a well-known technique from other areas of physics into atomic and molecular collisions research, and possibly lead to additional overlap and collaborations between the atomic collisions community and other related fields. Another important aspect of this project is the inclusion of undergraduate students in cutting-edge research. By participating in this project, students will gain valuable hands-on research experience through code development and data analysis. They will also present their results at regional and national conferences, which will hopefully give them a more global view of scientific research.

The few-body problem is one of the most fundamental, unsolved problems in physics. When more than two particles interact through the Coulomb force, the dynamics of the system cannot be described exactly. As a result, theory must resort to approximations, and any discrepancies that result between theory and experiment must be a result of the approximations. A comparison of current theoretical models with recent experimental results reveals some striking limitations of the current models. In particular, the dynamics of collisions in which some of the collision fragments are found in a full 3-dimensional geometry is not understood. The underlying mechanism behind these 3-dimensional collisions is known to be a result of quantum mechanical effects, but current theories cannot accurately describe the collision dynamics. The objective of this project is to develop a novel quantum mechanical theoretical model for the study of ion-impact atomic collisions through the use of the path integral technique. The path integral method is a well-known technique used in other areas of physics, but has not been applied to the study of heavy-ion collisions. This particular technique will allow for the inclusion of important quantum mechanical interactions, as well as provide an intuitive understanding of particle trajectories during the collision. 

The technical details of the project include the development of a computational model using the path integral method for ionization and capture processes with heavy-ion projectiles. The method will utilize an expansion of the Lagrangian around the classical path, where the deviation from the classical path represents the quantum fluctuations of the particle. For electron capture collisions, the role of the projectile-nuclear interaction and target electron correlation will be studied. Electron capture collisions with high projectile energy and large scattering angle will also be studied with the objective of better understanding the Thomas mechanism, and determining if possible diffraction effects exist in these collisions. For ionization processes, collisions in which the ejected electron is found outside of the scattering plane will be studied, with a focus on projectile-nuclear interactions and the role of close collisions between the projectile and the target nucleus.

por.por_cntn:
For over 2000 years, humans have searched for the most fundamental building blocks of matter.  The ancient Greeks referred to these particles as atoms, although we now know that atoms themselves consist of smaller particles, as do some of their constituent particles.  Discoveries about the structure of atoms have mostly been made through the field of atomic collisions, where electrons, protons, photons, and other small particles are fired at a target to determine the target?s structure and how the particles involved in the collision interact.  For the last century, atomic collisions have provided the basic understanding necessary for advances in fields as diverse as astronomy, medicine, computing, nanotechnology, and countless others.  Theoretical calculations combined with corresponding experimental measurements have yielded tremendous insight into the mechanisms of multiple interacting charged particles, making applications and developments in other fields possible.

Intellectual Merit: This grant has resulted in three significant advancements in the field of theoretical atomic collisions.  First, we developed the Path Integral Quantum Trajectory (PIQTr) model to study the time-dependent mechanics of heavy-particle collisions with atoms.  The PIQTr model provides a new tool that is computationally more efficient and yields greater insight into the dynamics of heavy-particle collisions.  We used our model to study the dynamics of matter Airy beams, finding that the time it takes a damaged Airy beam to recover its initial shape increases with the particle?s mass.  This indicates that for heavy particles, it?s unlikely the Airy beam will recover before a second interaction occurs, a result that has implications for proposed imaging applications. 

The second advancement we made was to present the first set of results for post-collision aligned ions in ionization collisions.  Most ionization collisions studied to date have been performed with the final state ion having a spherically symmetric charge distribution.  However, there is no physical requirement for spherical symmetry, and we showed that asymmetric ion alignment plays a key role in determining where the ionized electron is found.  Additionally, we showed that ionized electron location is controlled by angular momentum transfer from the atomic electrons and projectile.  This information provides the groundwork for future studies to guide applications for single atom or molecule control. 

The third advancement was to determine the applicability of a long-used approximation, known as the frozen core approximation.  This simplification is often used to make theories for collisions involving multi-electron targets tractable by neglecting electrons not directly involved in the collision.  For example, in a collision with a two-electron helium target, one of the atomic electrons would be neglected in the frozen core approximation.  Our models allow for the inclusion of both electrons in the calculation, and we showed that for ionization and capture collisions, the approximation is generally valid.  However, both electrons need to be included in the treatment of the projectile-target interaction.  This work provided important confirmation of a frequently-used approximation whose validity had not been specifically verified until now. 

Additionally, we initiated studies into non-traditional particle wave forms, such as electron vortex beams.  Known as twisted particles, our early work has demonstrated that these non-traditional matter wave forms interact with atoms in a very different way than their more conventional counterparts, opening the door to applications with tremendous potential in fields such as atomic and molecular control and electron microscopy.  This work is ongoing and aimed at providing needed information about fundamental interactions between twisted particles and atoms. 

Broader Impacts: A primary goal of our grant was the involvement and training of undergraduate students in physics research.  During the grant, 13 undergraduate students participated in our research and were trained in the latest physics and computational techniques.  The students coauthored 10 papers, gave 39 presentations at regional and national conferences, and won 6 awards, including a Goldwater Scholarship.  By attending and presenting at conferences, students gain valuable networking experience, as well as practice communicating their work to a wider audience.  Most of our students have gone onto careers in STEM fields or are continuing their studies.

The PI presented our work at several national and international conferences, including an invited talk at the 71st Gaseous Electronics Conference.  The PI also participated in science communication training through the Alda Center for Communicating Science and is working to improve science communication among Illinois State University researchers.  Our group?s research has been featured in numerous campus-wide publications, on the local National Public Radio station, and the PI was named to the 2019 Illinois Science and Technology Coalition?s Researchers to Know list.  The PI has also been fortunate to win several research and teaching awards at Illinois State University and has served on the organizing committees of the Gaseous Electronics Conference and the International Conference on Photonic, Electronic, and Atomic Collisions.  The results of our research are published in peer-reviewed journals and available open access through arxiv.org.
